column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column3: or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030, compared to the baseline set out in Article 27(1), in accordance with an indicative trajectory set by the Member State.
column6: The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.28, as the increased use of renewable fuels and electricity in the transport sector will lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, which will in turn support the development of sustainable and low-carbon transport infrastructure, including the deployment of recharging stations for heavy-duty electric vehicles.
column8: The share of energy from renewable sources used in transport in the EU reached 9.6 % in 2022, up from 9.1% in 2021.
column11: The growth in renewable energy share in transport, as targeted by TA2.13, will likely have a positive impact on TA4.29, as it will increase the demand for renewable fuels and electricity, driving the development of recharging infrastructure for heavy-duty electric vehicles.
column13: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025 and by at least 1.1 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2026 to 2030
column16: The implementation of TA2.14 may have a negative impact on TA4.30, as the increased demand for renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector may lead to competition for resources, potentially slowing down the deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations.
column18: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy.
column21: The progress towards TA2.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.31, as the increased share of renewable energy will drive the development of hydrogen production and refuelling infrastructure, supporting the deployment of hydrogen refuelling stations along the TEN-T core network.
column23: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030
column26: The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.32, as the increased use of renewable energy in the industry sector will drive the development of sustainable and low-carbon technologies, including the use of renewable energy to power aircraft and ships.
column28: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column31: The achievement of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.33, as increased electricity interconnection will facilitate the integration of renewable energy sources and support the development of shore-side electricity supply infrastructure for inland waterway vessels.
column33: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year, when compared to 2021.
column36: The implementation of TA2.21 may have a negative impact on TA4.34, as the reduced energy consumption of public bodies may lead to decreased demand for shore-side electricity supply infrastructure, potentially slowing down its development.
column38: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column41: The progress towards TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.55, as reduced energy consumption will lead to decreased emissions and support the development of sustainable and low-carbon transport modes, including zero-emission urban logistics.
column43: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030.
column46: The implementation of TA2.23 may have a negative impact on TA4.28, as reduced primary energy consumption may lead to decreased investment in renewable energy infrastructure, potentially slowing down the development of recharging stations for heavy-duty electric vehicles.
column48: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column51: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.30, as the renovation of buildings will increase the demand for renewable energy and support the development of hydrogen refuelling infrastructure.
column53: Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%
column56: The progress towards TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.32, as reduced energy consumption in buildings will lead to decreased emissions and support the development of sustainable and low-carbon technologies, including the use of renewable energy to power aircraft and ships.
column58: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column61: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.34, as increased energy renovation rates will lead to reduced energy consumption and support the development of shore-side electricity supply infrastructure for inland waterway vessels.
column63: Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column66: The implementation of TA2.28 may have a negative impact on TA4.33, as reduced energy consumption for heating and cooling may lead to decreased demand for shore-side electricity supply infrastructure, potentially slowing down its development.
column68: Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030 and, by 2033, the worst-performing 26% through minimum energy performance requirements
column71: The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.30, as the renovation of non-residential buildings will increase the demand for renewable energy and support the development of hydrogen refuelling infrastructure.
column73: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column76: The progress towards TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.31, as the renovation of worst-performing buildings will lead to reduced energy consumption and support the development of hydrogen production and refuelling infrastructure.
column78: Member States shall ensure that the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock decreases by at least 16% compared to 2020 by 2030
column81: The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.32, as reduced energy consumption in residential buildings will lead to decreased emissions and support the development of sustainable and low-carbon technologies, including the use of renewable energy to power aircraft and ships.
column83: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030, equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023, at least 1.3% in 2024-2025, 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030.
column86: The progress towards TA2.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.28, as cumulative energy savings will lead to reduced energy consumption and support the development of recharging infrastructure for heavy-duty electric vehicles.
column88: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030, equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023, at least 1.3% in 2024-2025, 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030.
column91: The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA4.55, as cumulative energy savings will lead to reduced energy consumption and support the development of sustainable and low-carbon transport modes, including zero-emission urban logistics.
column93: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column94: or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030, compared to the baseline set out in Article 27(1), in accordance with an indicative trajectory set by the Member State.
column97: The implementation of TA4.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.11, as the development of recharging infrastructure for heavy-duty electric vehicles will support the increased use of renewable fuels and electricity in the transport sector.
column99: By 31 December 2030, in each urban node publicly accessible recharging points dedicated to heavy-duty electric vehicles with an aggregated power output of at least 1 800 kW are deployed, provided by recharging stations with an individual power output of at least 150 kW.
column102: The implementation of TA4.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as the development of recharging infrastructure will support the increased use of renewable energy in the transport sector.
column104: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, at least one publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling station is deployed in each urban node.
column107: The implementation of TA4.30 may have a negative impact on TA2.14, as the development of hydrogen refuelling infrastructure may lead to competition for resources, potentially slowing down the development of renewable energy infrastructure for heating and cooling.
column109: Member States shall ensure that, by 31 December 2030, publicly accessible hydrogen refuelling stations with a total capacity of at least 1 tonne per day, and equipped with at least a 700 bar dispenser, are deployed at least every 200 km along the TEN-T (Trans-European Transport Network) core network.
column112: The implementation of TA4.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as the development of hydrogen refuelling infrastructure will support the increased use of renewable energy in the transport sector.
column114: States shall ensure that, at all airports of the TEN-T core network and TEN-T comprehensive network, the provision of electricity supply to stationary aircraft is ensured by 31 December 2029, at all aircraft remote stands used for commercial air transport operations to embark or disembark passengers or to load or unload goods.
column117: The implementation of TA4.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as the development of electricity supply infrastructure for aircraft will support the increased use of renewable energy in the industry sector.
column119: Member States shall ensure that at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T core inland waterway ports by 1 January 2025
column120: at least one installation providing shore-side electricity supply to inland waterway vessels is deployed at all TEN-T comprehensive inland waterway ports by 1 January 2030.
column123: The implementation of TA4.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as the development of shore-side electricity supply infrastructure will support the increased use of renewable energy and the development of electricity interconnection.
column125: Member States shall ensure that a minimum shore-side electricity supply for seagoing container ships and seagoing passenger ships is provided in TEN-T maritime ports.
column128: The implementation of TA4.34 may have a negative impact on TA2.22, as the development of shore-side electricity supply infrastructure may lead to increased energy consumption, potentially slowing down the reduction of energy consumption.
column133: The implementation of TA4.55 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25, as the development of zero-emission urban logistics will support the reduction of energy consumption in buildings.
column135: Reduce overall EU sales of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture by 50% by 2030.
column138: The implementation of TA5.2 may have a negative impact on TA2.11, as the reduction of antimicrobials may lead to increased energy consumption in the agricultural sector, potentially slowing down the development of renewable energy infrastructure.
column140: Reduce nutrient losses by at least 50%, while ensuring that there is no deterioration in soil fertility.
column143: The implementation of TA5.3 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as the reduction of nutrient losses will support the development of renewable energy infrastructure for heating and cooling.
column145: Reduce by 50% the use of more hazardous pesticides
column148: The implementation of TA5.4 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as the reduction of hazardous pesticides will support the development of renewable energy infrastructure in the transport sector.
column150: Reduce by 50% the use and risk of chemical pesticides
column153: The implementation of TA5.5 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as the reduction of chemical pesticides will support the increased use of renewable energy in the transport sector.
column155: Ensure that agriculture, fisheries and aquaculture, and the food value chain contribute to the target of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions to at least 55% below 1990 levels by 2030 and to the achievement of the objective for a climate-neutral Union in 2050.
column158: The implementation of TA5.6 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as the development of sustainable agriculture, fisheries, and aquaculture will support the increased use of renewable energy in the industry sector.
column160: Preserve freshwater, boost water reuse in agriculture.
column163: The implementation of TA5.7 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as the preservation of freshwater and the development of water reuse in agriculture will support the development of electricity interconnection and the increased use of renewable energy.
column165: Increase organic farming with the aim to achieve at least 25% of total farmland under organic farming by 2030
column168: The implementation of TA5.8 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as the development of organic farming will support the development of renewable energy infrastructure for heating and cooling.
column170: Increase renewable energy in the agriculture and food sector.
column173: The implementation of TA5.9 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as the development of renewable energy in the agriculture and food sector will support the increased use of renewable energy in the transport sector.
column175: Energy: Increase renewable energy in the agriculture and food sector, adopt energy efficiency solutions in the agriculture and food sector, by reducing energy consumption.
column178: The implementation of TA5.10 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as the development of renewable energy and energy efficiency solutions in the agriculture and food sector will support the increased use of renewable energy in the transport sector.
